awd_titl_txt: International Workshop on Sustainable Smart Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will bring together, in Egypt, 15 senior and 3 student participants from the US to meet with approximately 60 participants from Egypt and other countries in the Middle East and Europe to discuss and plan future research on Sustainable Smart Cities. 

Research on sustainable urban infrastructure and living is urgently needed as the pace of urbanization continues to increase. Some estimates suggest that by 2050 70% of the world?s population will live in cities. Already nearly one billion people live in urban slums that lack basic services like water and electricity. At the same time, cities consume a tremendous share of resources like water and energy for which demand globally is only increasing. Urbanization is increasing most rapidly in developing countries, making the topic of sustainable cities particularly valuable for collaboration between US and developing country scientists. Egypt is a particularly valuable location for this meeting, with Cairo facing some of the greatest urban infrastructure challenges of any city in the world. 

The main goals of the workshop are to:
A.	Provide a forum for engineers, scientists and planners to discuss current research on sustainable smart cities.
B.	Establish an international collaborative research agenda and promote joint research between
C.	US and Egyptian scientists in urban sustainability
D.	Outline opportunities for junior researchers in the form of training courses, fellowships, and educational exchanges

The topics proposed for the three-day meeting are:
1.	Sustainable Smart City Planning and Infrastructure
2.	The Built Environment
3.	Economic Aspects of Urban Development (Sustainable Smart Tourism)
4.	Impact of Smart Cities on Health and Quality of Life,
5.	The Role of Higher Education in Sustainable Smart Cities 

The overarching topic and selected themes are timely. Research efforts are underway in the US and around the world to find ways for cities to operate and grow that are efficient, attractive and economical while also supporting the needs of residents. This workshop will bring together experts from the US, Egypt, the rest of the Middle East/North Africa (MENA) and Europe to share results, coordinate new collaborative research endeavors and develop training materials, all of which will be valuable in the US and around the world. Because this meeting will bring together researchers committed to understanding and improving urban areas in developing countries, the potential for valuable knowledge exchange and longer term collaboration is tremendous. 

Funding for this project is provided by the Office of International Science and Engineering through the US-Egypt Joint Fund.

por.por_cntn:
The 2017 NSF Sustainable Smart Cities International Workshop in Alexandria, Egypt brought together global experts to discuss significant research and technological developments in the field of urban sustainability, particularly as it relates to developing countries. Participants shared information and experiences related to the five program themes: the built environment, urban economic development, health and quality of life, social sustainability, and urban informatics.  The highly successful 3-day workshop laid the groundwork for future research collaborations and generated partnerships between U.S. and Egyptian researchers.

At the conclusion of the 2017 workshop, participants recommended that a follow-up workshop be held, with the goal of directly engaging stakeholders and decision makers from the Egyptian national government as well as other major cities in Egypt, such as Cairo. Several workshop participants noted that the most productive elements of the workshop were the Day 2 task group working sessions and the Day 3 discussions. Participants would have liked to have had more of these types of these interactive activities, as well as more time in the agenda for question and answer periods following the formal presentations. In addition, several Egyptian participants noted the need to have more representatives from the Egyptian government present and more people from younger age groups represented. 

In response to the recommendations and suggestions of the initial workshop in 2017, the 2nd NSF Sustainable Smart Cities International Workshop was held in Cairo, Egypt on June 11-13, 2019. Remaining funds from the 2017 workshop were used for the follow up workshop. This workshop was organized to promote interdisciplinary collaboration and the exchange of knowledge related to advancing sustainable urbanization in arid regions. The broad goal was to bring together decision making, research, and practitioner communities from the U.S., U.K., and Egypt to facilitate open discussions and exchange of knowledge related to the challenges of advancing sustainable smart cities and the role of national and local governments in those efforts. As a result of these workshops, a number of international research teams have formed that continue to develop projects and proposals for collaborative research.

As the major activity during the reporting period, we have continued communication with key participants from both workshops and shared progress via the project website: https://www.uab.edu/engineering/smartcities/nsf-international-workshop-2019
